verses.text: At that time Herod the tetrarch heard the reports about Jesus,
verses.comment: The account of Herod's reaction connects the events in Jesus' ministry to recent political events in Judea.

verses.text: and he said to his servants, 'This is John the Baptist. He has been raised from the dead; that is why miraculous powers are at work in him.'
verses.comment: Herod’s superstition reflects a belief in resurrection, showing the lingering impact John the Baptist had, and foreshadows Jesus’ own resurrection.

verses.text: For Herod had arrested John, bound him, and put him in prison for the sake of Herodias, his brother Philip’s wife,
verses.comment: Explains the backstory for John's imprisonment, highlighting John's courage in confronting sin.

verses.text: because John had been saying to him, 'It is not lawful for you to have her.'
verses.comment: John’s insistence on God’s moral law reveals prophetic boldness, drawing on the Law of Moses as authority.

verses.text: Though Herod wanted to put him to death, he feared the people, because they regarded John as a prophet.
verses.comment: Herod's fear of the popular opinion demonstrates the authority the prophets had among the people, prefiguring Christ’s own reputation.

verses.text: But when Herod’s birthday was celebrated, the daughter of Herodias danced before them and pleased Herod,
verses.comment: Sets the stage for John’s martyrdom, underscoring intrigue and moral darkness in Herod’s court.

verses.text: so he promised with an oath to give her whatever she asked.
verses.comment: The rash oath draws a parallel to other Old Testament vows that led to tragedy.

verses.text: Prompted by her mother, she said, 'Give me here on a platter the head of John the Baptist.'
verses.comment: The demand for John’s head demonstrates the cost of speaking God’s truth and anticipates other martyrs in Christian history.

verses.text: The king was deeply grieved, but because of his oaths and because of those who sat at table with him, he commanded it to be given.
verses.comment: Political concerns and personal pride can lead to grave evil. Compare Pilate’s dilemma with Jesus later.

verses.text: So he sent and had John beheaded in the prison.
verses.comment: John’s death as a martyr prepares the way for Christ, who will also be unjustly executed.

verses.text: His head was brought on a platter and given to the girl, and she brought it to her mother.
verses.comment: Shows the injustice and brutality that often befell God’s prophets.

verses.text: John’s disciples came and took the body and buried it. Then they went and told Jesus.
verses.comment: Provides a parallel to Jesus’ own burial by his disciples after crucifixion. The honor given to John’s remains prefigures Christian reverence for those who died for the faith.

verses.text: When Jesus heard this, he withdrew from there in a boat to a deserted place by himself. But when the crowds heard it, they followed him on foot from the towns.
verses.comment: Jesus’ withdrawal reflects both his humanity—seeking solitude in grief—and his divine compassion, as crowds seek him out.

verses.text: When he went ashore, he saw a great crowd, and he was moved with compassion for them and healed their sick.
verses.comment: Jesus’ compassion is a recurring theme and a mark of the Messiah’s ministry (see Isaiah 53:4), fulfilled in Christ’s mercy.

verses.text: When it was evening, the disciples came to him and said, 'This is a deserted place, and the hour is now late. Send the crowds away to go into the villages and buy food for themselves.'
verses.comment: The disciples’ request sets the stage for a miracle prefiguring the Lord’s Supper.

verses.text: But Jesus said to them, 'They do not need to go away; you give them something to eat.'
verses.comment: Jesus directs the disciples to take part in his ministry, foreshadowing the ongoing ministry and provision through those he appoints.

verses.text: They said to him, 'We have here only five loaves and two fish.'
verses.comment: The insufficiency of human resources allows Christ’s divine abundance to be revealed.

verses.text: He said, 'Bring them here to me.'
verses.comment: Jesus asks for what they have, regardless of how little—a model for our offerings and spiritual cooperation with His work.

verses.text: Then he commanded the crowds to sit down on the grass. Taking the five loaves and the two fish, looking up to heaven, he blessed and broke the loaves and gave them to the disciples, and the disciples gave them to the crowds.
verses.comment: Jesus’ actions imitate the actions at the Last Supper, foreshadowing the Eucharist (see John 6:11). Christ mediates grace through appointed leaders, who distribute the miraculous bread—a spiritual and literal feeding.

verses.text: They all ate and were satisfied. They took up twelve baskets full of the broken pieces left over.
verses.comment: The abundance left over underscores the superabundance of God’s grace and provision, with twelve baskets recalling the twelve tribes and later the apostles.

verses.text: Those who ate were about five thousand men, besides women and children.
verses.comment: Indicates the magnitude of this sign, supporting its literal and spiritual meanings as a sign of God’s kingdom.

verses.text: Immediately after, he compelled the disciples to get into the boat and go ahead of him to the other side, while he dismissed the crowds.
verses.comment: Jesus' authority over his disciples and the crowds further demonstrates his role as leader and teacher.

verses.text: After he dismissed the crowds, he went up on the mountain by himself to pray. When evening came, he was there alone.
verses.comment: Jesus’ habit of solitary prayer underlines his intimate relationship with the Father, modeling devotion for his followers.

verses.text: But the boat was already far from land, battered by the waves, for the wind was against it.
verses.comment: The disciples’ journey and the storm symbolize the trials the Church will encounter apart from Christ’s visible presence.

verses.text: In the fourth watch of the night, he came to them, walking on the sea.
verses.comment: Walking on the water is a sign of divinity (Job 9:8—God alone treads the waves), literally demonstrating Jesus as true God.

verses.text: When the disciples saw him walking on the sea, they were terrified and said, 'It is a ghost!' and they cried out in fear.
verses.comment: The disciples’ fear reveals their limited understanding of Jesus’ divine nature and the mystery of the Incarnation.

verses.text: But immediately Jesus spoke to them, saying, 'Take courage; it is I. Do not be afraid.'
verses.comment: ‘It is I’ (Greek: ego eimi, ‘I am’) echoes God’s self-revelation in the Old Testament, further highlighting Jesus’ divinity.

verses.text: Peter answered him, 'Lord, if it is you, command me to come to you on the water.'
verses.comment: Peter’s response is both an act of faith and an acknowledgment of Christ’s authority.

verses.text: 'Come,' he said. So Peter got out of the boat and walked on the water toward Jesus.
verses.comment: Jesus shares his divine power with Peter when Peter acts in faith, anticipating later authority given to Peter.

verses.text: But when he saw the wind, he was afraid, and beginning to sink, he cried out, 'Lord, save me!'
verses.comment: Peter’s faltering faith illustrates the human need for Christ’s saving help in the midst of trials.

verses.text: Immediately Jesus reached out his hand and took hold of him, saying, 'O you of little faith, why did you doubt?'
verses.comment: Christ’s rebuke is gentle correction for Peter; even the leaders among the disciples sometimes falter, but Christ remains their sure support.

verses.text: When they got into the boat, the wind ceased.
verses.comment: Christ’s command over nature demonstrates his sovereignty and divinity.

verses.text: Then those who were in the boat worshipped him, saying, 'Truly you are the Son of God.'
verses.comment: The disciples worship Jesus—a response reserved for God alone—confessing his divine Sonship, which is a pivotal moment in the Gospel.

verses.text: When they had crossed over, they came to land at Gennesaret.
verses.comment: Marks a transition in Jesus' ministry, leading to further miracles among the people.

verses.text: And when the men of that place recognized him, they sent word into all that surrounding region and brought to him all who were sick.
verses.comment: Demonstrates the spread of Jesus’ reputation and fulfillment of Messianic healing prophecies.

verses.text: They pleaded with him that they might only touch the fringe of his cloak, and as many as touched it were healed.
verses.comment: Touching the fringe of Jesus’ garment recalls the power mediated by physical contact, symbolizing the sacramental principle: God's grace is communicated through outward signs. This points to a tangible means by which God conveys His power to humanity.
